_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Greater Omaha Packing Co., Inc.

RMP Executive Summary



A

Accidental Release prevention includes the following: 

1. Programs listed in Section 7.4e of the RMP including the following:  

Vents                Automatic Shutoffs

Relief valves            Interlocks

Check valves            Alarms and procedures

Manual Shutoffs        Purge System



2. Training of all employees responsible for maintaining the ammonia refrigeration.  



3. Extensive maintenance programs involving hourly, daily, weekly, & monthly     

      inspections of process equipment



4. Preventive maintenance programs requiring the service or replacement of process systems                      

     before inefficiencies occur.   



Emergency Response Policies

1. Greater Omaha Packing Company Inc. will establish an Emergency Response Plan.

2. Key management personnel at GOP will follow the "Team Assignment Checklist for an Ammonia Leak"   

3. All employees at Greater Omaha Packing Company (GOP) will be trained in their role in the emergency response plan when they are hired and at least annually thereafter.  



B

The stationary source at Greater Omaha Packing Company Inc. is the ammonia refrigeration system. This system contains ammonia in the amount over the threshold requiring an RMP. 



C

Worst - Case Scenario

The worst - case scenario was determined by finding the largest vessel containing the most ammonia. This vessel is also located outdoors. This vessel is the ammonia receiver located on the south side of the plant. According to the Plant Engineer , this vessel could contain as much as 10000 lbs. of ammonia, which is the maximum capacity of the receiver. This amount is used as the quantity Q since for the worst - case scenario, the vessel is assumed to be full. The time of release is 10 minutes. The rate of release, R, is calculated as 10000 lbs / 10 minutes = 1000 lbs. / minute. 



Q = 10000 lbs. ammonia

T = 10 minutes

R = 1000 lbs. Ammonia / minute



C

Using Exhibit 4-4 from the EPA's Risk Manageme

nt Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration with a release rate of 1000 lbs / minute the distance to the endpoint is 1.2 miles. This radius and the surrounding area are drawn on the city map of Omaha. Using information from the Census Bureau, the population enclosed by a radius of 1.2 miles from the source is 850.



Alternative Scenario

The alternative scenario was chosen by contemplating scenarios involving off - site consequences. A broken 1/2 " pipe located on the roof was chosen as the source of the release. This scenario involves a release of 640 pounds / minute over a 10 minute period. The toxic endpoint of 0.2 miles was obtained. The population within this radius is 170.    



D

General Accidental Release Policies include the following: 

1. Programs listed in Section 7.4e of the RMP.  



2. Training of all employees responsible for maintaining the ammonia refrigeration.  



3. Extensive maintenance programs involving hourly, daily, weekly, & monthly  inspections of process equipment



4. Preventive maintenance programs requiring the service or replacement of process systems before inefficiencies occur.   



Chemical - specific prevention steps include using only process equipment designed for use in an ammonia refrigeration system. 



E

Greater Omaha Packing Company has had no accidental chemical releases within the past five years. 





F



General Procedures for Emergency Action Plans







Management is responsible for redeveloping an emergency plan to handle all types of emergencies, (tornado, earthquake, fire, ammonia line break, etc.).  Each plant must decide on a plan that fits their needs.  Main consideration and planning for disaster control must include provisions for protecting personnel, evacuation both injured and uninjured and care of the incapacitated.  While certain basic elements would be common to all plans, the same complete plan could not, for example, be used for both an ammonia line break and a tornado.



Each location m

ust post an evacuation plan for each floor and all departments indicating the location of all emergency exits and exit routes.



Supervisors in each department shall assist all employees in case of an evacuation.  It shall be the responsibility of the supervisor to orderly evacuate all personnel in the area of his/her responsibility and that roll-call is held in the designated assembly area so that all personnel are accounted for.



Only trained personnel in the use of fire extinguishers may use them to contain fires in the incipient stage. 



In order to assure the safety of all personnel, the following policy and instructions are published for emergencies as scheduled:

Ammonia Line Break Procedures:



In the event of an ammonia line break, the following action will be taken:



1. When the order to evacuate is given, evacuate immediately through designated exits and emergency exit routes to designated assembly areas, where roll-call will be taken and all personnel accounted for.

2. Management will assign and train personnel in the proper use and care of gas masks and/or respirators as defined in ANSIZ99.2-1969.



Written procedures shall be prepared covering safe use of the respirators in dangerous atmospheres that might be encountered in normal operations or in emergencies.  Personnel shall be familiar with these procedures and the available respirators.

In areas where the wearer, with failure of the respirator, could be overcome by a toxic or oxygen-deficient atmosphere, at least one additional man shall be present.

Communications (visual, voice, or signal line) shall be maintained between both individuals present.  Planning shall be such that one individual will be unaffected by any likely incident and have the proper rescue equipment to be able to assist the other(s) in case of emergency.





Management's Response to a Chemical Release

Assignments have been made to individual members of the management team. A written "Team Assignment Checklist" give

s specific responsibilities to the management team. Training has been provided to team members. 



Vapor Cloud Monitoring

Greater Omaha Packing, the police department, and fire department, will collaborate on vapor cloud monitoring and keep each party informed of its progress. Greater Omaha Packing Company will notify media of a chemical threat. 



Public Notification

Greater Omaha Packing will notify media of chemical release and precautions that the public should take such as staying indoors with the doors closed and windows shut. 



Site and Traffic Control

The police department agreed to provide site and traffic control for Greater Omaha Packing in the event of a release. The worst case scenario was discussed and police reviewed areas that would be affected. Police reviewed possible sites to restrict or block traffic.



Emergency Rescue

The fire department has agreed to provide emergency rescue operations at Greater Omaha Packing Co. as necessary and to the public as well in the event of a chemical release.







TEAM ASSIGNMENT CHECKLIST

 Ammonia Leak

 

FABRICATION PLANS

Notify Supervisors via radios to evacuate employees.

Evacuate personnel from front office

Call emergency service (fire, rescue)

Retrieve time sheets for roll call

Count employees after outside to make sure everyone is out

Check plant to make sure everyone is out.

Rescue employees as necessary            

Administer first aid, CPR, etc...

Meet fire department and direct them to the emergency

Authorized person to talk to reporters

Contain ammonia leak

Close designated fluid/gas lines

Keep unauthorized people off premises

Shut down electrical / mechanical system

Keep log of incoming calls (date/time/caller/discussion)

Keep log of outgoing calls

Take photos of damage and conditions for documentation

Phone employees' families to advise of employees' safety

Phone officials (city, OSHA, EPA, health department)

Contact Insurance /Legal 

Authorize return to work







T

EAM ASSIGNMENT CHECKLIST

 Ammonia Leak

 

SLAUGHTER PLANS

Notify Supervisors via radios to evacuate employees.

Call emergency service (fire, rescue)

Retrieve time sheets for roll call

Count employees after outside to make sure everyone is out

Check plant to make sure everyone is out.

Rescue employees as necessary            

Administer first aid, CPR, etc...

Meet fire department and direct them to the emergency

Authorized person to talk to reporters

Contain ammonia leak

Close designated fluid/gas lines

Keep unauthorized people off premises

Shut down electrical / mechanical system

Keep log of incoming calls (date/time/caller/discussion)

Keep log of outgoing calls

Take photos of damage and conditions for documentation

Protect product as possible

Phone employees' families to advise of employees' safety

Phone suppliers/ customers

Phone officials (city, OSHA, EPA, health department

Authorize return to work



G

The company has not had any releases in more than five years. The company plans to continue with extensive maintenance programs already in place. 



Kathleen Krantz

Technical Resource Director
